article.title: Bagpuss
article.paragraph:
Use dmy datesJuly 2012Infobox televisionBagpuss [[File:Bagpuss.jpg|200px]] The original Bagpuss as seen in the series
[[Peter Firmin]] and [[Oliver Postgate]] The voices of Oliver Postgate Sandra Kerr and John Faulkner. [[Oliver Postgate]] UK [[BBC1]] 12 February 1974 7 May 1974 13 Bagpussis a Britishchildren's television series, made byPeter FirminandOliver Postgate. The series of 13 episodes was first broadcast from 12 February 1974cite newshttp://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/tvandradio/10631604/Happy-40th-birthday-Bagpuss.html Happy 40th birthday, Bagpuss!RuncieCharlotte 12 February 2014[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]] 12 February 2014 to 7 May 1974 through their companySmallfilms. The title character was "a saggy, old cloth cat, baggy, and a bit loose at the seams".cite webhttp://www.smallfilms.co.uk/bagpuss/intro.htmBagpuss – The intro11 November 2007The Smallfilms Treasuryhttp://web.archive.org/web/20071221021416/http://www.smallfilms.co.uk/bagpuss/intro.htm21 December 2007noAlthough only 13 episodes were made, it remains fondly remembered,cite webhttp://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/magazine/7773124.stmBagpuss – See Emily Play12 September 2008BBC9 December 2008and was frequently repeated in the UK for 13 years.citationHaywardAnthonyPostgate, (Richard) Oliver (1925–2008)Oxford Dictionary of National BiographyOxford University Press2012http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/10067828 May 2012ODNBsubIn 1999Bagpusstopped a BBC poll for the UK's favourite children's TV programme.
article.heading: Format
article.paragraph: Each programme began in the same way: through a series ofsepia tonesepiaphotographs, the viewer is told of a little girl named Emily (played by Emily Firmin, the daughter of illustrator Firmin),cite webDuffyJonathanhttp://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/magazine/7773124.stmUK | Magazine | See Emily playBBC News9 December 200824 July 2009who owned a shop. Emily found lost and broken things and displayed them in the window, so their owners could come and collect them; the shop did not sell anything. She would leave the object in front of her favourite stuffed toy, the large, saggy, pink and white striped cat named Bagpuss, originally intended by Firmin to be a retired Indian Army cat who entertained children in the hospital with his "visible" thoughts appearing in a "thinks bubble" above his head. When Postgate and Firmin were asked to develop this character for a BBC programme Postgate placed him in the shop with other characters and his "thinks bubble" became a way to illustrate the stories and mend or explore the objects that Emily had found. Emily then recited a verse:

template.arg:
Bagpuss, dear Bagpuss
Old Fat Furry Catpuss
Wake up and look at this thing that I bring
Wake up, be bright, be golden and light
Bagpuss, oh hear what I sing

article.paragraph: When Emily had left, Bagpuss woke up. The programme shifted from sepia to colourstop motionfilm, and various toys in the shop came to life: Gabriel the toad (who, unlike most Smallfilms characters, could move by a special device beneath his can without the use of stop motion animation) and arag dollcalled Madeleine. The wooden woodpecker bookend became the drily academic ProfessorYaffle(based on the philosopherBertrand Russell, whom Postgate had once met),Channel 4News, 9 December 2008.while the mice carved on the side of the "mouse organ" (a small mechanicalpipe organthat played rolls of music) woke up and scurried around, singing in high-pitched voices.Sandra KerrandJohn Faulkner (musician)John Faulknerprovided the voices of Madeleine and Gabriel respectively, and put together and performed all thefolk songs. All the other voices (including the narrator and one out-of-tune mouse) were provided byOliver PostgatePostgate, who also wrote the stories.

The toys discussed what the new object was; someone (usually Madeleine) would tell a story related to the object (shown in an animated thought bubble over Bagpuss's head), often with a song, accompanied by Gabriel on thebanjo(which often sounded a lot more like a guitar), and then the mice, singing in high-pitched squeaky harmony to the tune ofSumer Is Icumen Inas they worked, mended the broken object. The newly mended thing was then placed in the shop window, so that whomever had lost it would see it as they went past, and could come in and claim it. Then Bagpuss would start yawning again, and as he fell asleep the narrator would speak as the colour faded to sepia and they all became toys again.

template.arg:
And so their work was done.
Bagpuss gave a big yawn and settled down to sleep
And, of course, when Bagpuss goes to sleep,
All his friends go to sleep too.
The mice were ornaments on the mouse organ.
Gabriel and Madeleine were just dolls.
And Professor Yaffle was a carved, wooden [[bookend]] in the shape of a woodpecker.
Even Bagpuss himself, once he was asleep, was just an old, saggy cloth cat,
Baggy, and a bit loose at the seams,
But Emily loved him.

article.heading: Title sequence
article.paragraph: The scene is set at the turn of the 20th century, with Emily Firmin playing the part of theVictorian eraVictorianchild Emily.Postgate, Oliver (2000)Seeing Things-A MemoirISBN 978-1-84767-840-9The first antique village vignette is a cropped image ofHorrabridgetaken in 1898, though nothing is known of the other photo of the children with the pram.cite webFrancis Frith Archivehttp://www.francisfrith.com/horrabridge/22 November 2011The shop window was at the Firmin family home inBlean.
article.heading: Episodes
article.paragraph: The episodes used to be on at 1:45pm on BBC1 and the titles of the episodes each refer in some way to the object Emily found.cite webhttp://www.smallfilms.co.uk/bagpuss/stories.htm The StoriesSmallfilms 26 February 2014

tablerow.tablecell: Some splints of wood are shaken out of a bottle by the mice. Bagpuss tells a story about mermaids and the magic repairs the model ship. The mice put it back into the bottle and raise the sails.
A dirty rag reveals a picture of an owl once cleaned. Madeleine recounts a story explaining why owls sound like they do. Gabriel recounts in song the story of a king who needed a cushion to sit on.
Assorted jewels, which initially are thought to represent a cat and mouse but which Gabriel decides were the crown jewels of a frog princess.
Put to inventive use by the mice, and the subject of a very silly song about its possible use as arowing boat.
Atartanporcupinepincushion, and a legend of a small, soft creature from Scotland.
A broken figurine of a Chinese man (the Wise Man of Ling-Po, Yaffle explains) and a turtle.

A wooden toyMill (grinding)milldemonstrated by the mice to make chocolate biscuits out ofLima beanbutterbeansand breadcrumbs. This turns out to be a mischievous fraud. Gabriel and Madeleine sing a song about how ploughmen, farmers, millers and bakers work at different stages of bread production. Even stern old Professor Yaffle cries.
Astatuette, and a lesson about how sizes are relative.
A basket that the mice attempt to turn into a flying machine.
A piece of cloth, destined to be a house for a rag doll.

article.heading: VHS and DVD releases
article.paragraph: In May 1999,PolyGramreleased a video entitledThe Complete Bagpusswhich included all 13 episodes.cite webhttp://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/341007.stm Made in the 70s, still going strongBBC News 17 May 199926 February 2014cite webhttp://www.smallfilms.co.uk/bagpuss/video.htm The Video and DVDSmallfilms 26 February 2014It was released in DVD format in April 2005.cite webhttp://www.bbcshop.com/Childrens/Bagpuss-The-Complete-Bagpuss-Animated-DVD/invt/8234175 Bagpuss: The Complete Bagpuss (Animated) (DVD) BBCSHOP.COM 26 February 2014It was re-released in DVD format in April 2015.
The first video was released by Channel 5 and the rest were released by Universal Pictures.

article.heading: Production
article.paragraph: The programmes were made usingstop motionstop-frame animation. Bagpuss is an actual cloth cat, but was not intended to be such an electric pink. "It should have been a ginger marmalade cat but the company inFolkestonedyeing the material made a mistake and it turned out pink and cream. It was the best thing that ever happened," said Firmin.cite newsSaggy old cloth cat pulls in the crowdsCanterbury AdsceneKent Regional News and Media4–59 November 2007
Madeleine the rag doll was made by Firmin's wife, Joan, with an extra long dress to hold their children's nightdresses, but Postgate asked Joan to make a new version as one of the characters.

Gabriel the Toad was the only character in the series who could move freely without the use of stop-frame animation. Scenes featuring him playing the banjo and singing would have taken quite a bit of time if filmed with the stop-frame method, so Peter Firmin created a mechanism that helped him control Gabriel through a hole in his can.The character was based on a real toad that lived in the basement area of the flat that Peter and Joan Firmin rented in Twickenham beside the River Thames. Peter first made Gabriel (named after Walter Gabriel inList of The Archers characters''The Archers'', a long-running British radio soap opera) for his live ITV programme "The Musical Box". Oliver chose him as one of the characters in Bagpuss and Peter made a new, slightly larger version.

Professor Yaffle was created as the Bookend who had access to "facts". The BBC did not like Peter's first character, a man in top hat made from Black Irish bogwood called "Professor Bogwood". They thought it was too frightening and asked for a non-human instead.

Bagpuss has now retired to theRupert Bear MuseuminCanterbury, part of theMuseum of Canterbury, together with other characters and Emily's shop window.cite newshttp://www.kentonline.co.uk/kentonline/newsarchive.aspx?articleidKent Messenger14 April 2003Easter opening for Rupert Bear museum23 February 2013
Most of the stories and songs used in the series are based on folk songs andfairy talesfrom around the world.
article.heading: Recognition
article.paragraph: In 1987 theUniversity of KentUniversity of Kent at Canterburyawardedhonorary degreesto Postgate and Firmin. In his speech, Postgate stated that the degree was really intended for Bagpuss, who was subsequently displayed in academic dress.cite webhttp://www.kent.ac.uk/arts/campus/chronicle.htmlA Canterbury ChronicleArts, leisure and public eventsUniversity of Kent29 November 2006http://web.archive.org/web/20070930024111/http://www.kent.ac.uk/arts/campus/chronicle.html30 September 2007

In 1999 the series came first in a BBC poll selecting the nation's favourite children's show.cite newsEntertainment: Bagpuss cream of television[[BBC News]]1 October 1999http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/246080.stm21 September 2007LondonIt also came fourth in the 2001Channel 4poll, the100 Greatest Kids' TV shows.cite newsSimpsons tops kids' TV poll[[BBC News]]28 September 2001http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/tv_and_radio/1512890.stm21 September 2007

In 2002 and 2005 a stage show ofBagpusssongs toured UKfolk festivalsand theatres with original singersSandra KerrandJohn Faulkner (musician)John Faulkner, along with Kerr's daughterNancy Kerrand her husband, James Fagan.

In June 2002, the charityHospices of Hopeopened the Bagpuss Children's Wing in its hospice inBraov,Romania. The wing was funded entirely byOliver PostgatePostgatefromroyaltiesreceived from theBBC. In April 2012,Marc JennerfromTunbridge Wellsin Kent ran in theVirgin London Marathondressed in aconvert7ftonBagpuss costume to raise money for the charity, supported byEmily FirminandOliver PostgatePostgate's family.

Thom Yorkeof the bandRadioheadhas claimed to be a fan of the show, watching it with his son. It was an influence for 2003 albumHail to the Thief. Gabriel's song in Episode 2 was the acknowledged inspiration for the album track (and first single) "There There" (originally titled "The Bony King of Nowhere").http://pulk-pull.org/message-124-bagpuss/

The character appeared on one of the twelve postage stamps issued byRoyal Mailin January 2014 to celebrate classic children's programmes.cite newshttp://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/gallery/2014/jan/04/royal-mail-childrens-tv-stamps-in-pictures?pictureRoyal Mail's children's TV stamps – in pictures 4 January 2014[[The Guardian]] 12 February 2014
